The highest known sale price for any artwork was $300 million for Willem de Kooning’s “Interchange,” sold privately in September 2015 by the David Geffen Foundation to hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffin.
It was put up for sale Wednesday by Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev, who bought it in 2013 for $127 million in a private sale that became the subject of a continuing lawsuit.
The 26-inch tall painting of Christ, called “Salvator Mundi,” or “Savior of the World,” was purchased by an unknown buyer at a Christie’s auction.
It far surpassed the prior record set for a painting at auction — Pablo Picasso’s “Women of Algiers,” which sold for $179 million in May 2015.
Visitors at Christie's wait outside in a line to view Leonardo da Vinci's "Salvator Mundi", Tuesday, Nov. 14, 2017.
It’s one of fewer than 20 paintings by the Renaissance master known to exist and the only one in private hands.
In 9 minutes of bidding, a Leonardo da Vinci masterpiece sold for a record-setting $450 million Wednesday.
The final price of $450 million includes a fee paid by the winner to the auction house.
Dating to the 1500s, the da Vinci was once owned by King Charles I of England.
